syllabus.course_title: Python Foundations: From Logic to Application
syllabus.course_objective: To provide learners with a rigorous foundation in Python syntax, logical programming structures, and hands-on problem-solving skills through a structured, evidence-based pedagogy.

lessons.title: Foundation and Environment: Getting Started with Python
objectives: Identify prerequisites including basic computer literacy and fundamental arithmetic required for programming.
Successfully install the Python interpreter and verify environment variables (PATH).
Configure a professional Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for script management.
Execute basic Input/Output operations using the print() function and the standard REPL.
Define the Evidence-Based Pedagogy framework (Active Recall and Scaffolding) used throughout this course.
content_outline: Course Prerequisites: Basic file management skills and middle-school level algebra (operators).
The Python Ecosystem: Understanding Python's role as a high-level, interpreted language.
Installation & Environment: Downloading Python 3.x, verifying versions, and an overview of the PATH variable.
Development Tools: Comparative analysis of VS Code and PyCharm; why we use scripts vs. the REPL.
Foundational I/O: Introduction to the print() function for user output.
Pedagogical Framework: Explanation of the 'Synthesis Project' (cumulative final) and how 'Memory' lessons relate to Variable assignment and RAM.
activities: System Configuration: Guided installation of Python 3.x and VS Code.
REPL Interaction: Using the Read-Eval-Print Loop as a persistent calculator to test basic arithmetic (+, -, *, /).
The 'Hello World' Script: Creating, saving, and executing a .py file via the terminal.
Error Literacy: Introduction to SyntaxError by intentionally breaking code (missing quotes) to build debugging confidence.
Initial Diagnostic: A short quiz on mathematical operator precedence to ensure prerequisite alignment.
resources: Python.org Installation Hub: https://www.python.org/downloads/
Visual Studio Code - Python Setup Guide: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/python/python-tutorial
Real Python: 'Python 3 Installation & Setup Guide'
citations: Van Rossum, G., & Drake, F. L. (2009). Python 3 Reference Manual. CreateSpace.
Brown, P. C., Roediger, H. L., & McDaniel, M. A. (2014). Make It Stick: The Science of Successful Learning (Context for Pedagogy).
Matthes, E. (2023). Python Crash Course, 3rd Edition. No Starch Press.

lessons.title: Data Foundations: Variables, Types, and Basic I/O
objectives: Differentiate between primitive data types: integers (int), floats (float), strings (str), and booleans (bool).
Analyze Python's memory model where variables act as labels referring to objects in computer RAM.
Perform basic user interactions using the input() and print() functions.
Apply PEP 8 naming conventions to ensure code readability and professional standards.
Utilize the type() and id() functions to inspect data types and memory addresses.
content_outline: Prerequisite Review: Verification of environment setup (Python/IDE) and basic computer literacy.
Mental Models of Memory: Moving from 'variables as boxes' to 'variables as name-tags' (references) in computer memory.
Introduction to Basic I/O: Capturing user text via input() and displaying results via print().
Numeric Types & Math Prep: Decimals (floats) vs. Whole numbers (ints) and their hardware representation.
String Fundamentals: Initial introduction to text data as a sequence of characters.
Dynamic Typing: Understanding how Python determines types at runtime without explicit declaration.
Variable Semantics: Legal syntax vs. PEP 8 stylistic best practices (snake_case).
activities: Interactive Shell Exercise: Using id() to reveal the 'address' of a variable in memory.
The 'Greeter' Script: Writing a program that asks for a user's name (str) and age (int), then prints a customized message.
Conversion Lab: Experimenting with type casting (e.g., int('5')) to resolve errors when input() returns a string.
Variable Naming Audit: A peer-review activity identifying 'bad' variable names (e.g., 1_var, MyVariable, x) and correcting them to PEP 8 standards.
resources: Python 3 Documentation: Built-in Functions (input, print, type)
Thonny IDE: Visualizer tool (highly recommended for seeing variables in memory)
PEP 8 -- Style Guide for Python Code (Naming Conventions section)
citations: Van Rossum, G., & Drake, F. L. (2023). Python 3.12 Documentation. Python Software Foundation.
Ramalho, L. (2022). Fluent Python: Clear, Concise, and Effective Programming. O'Reilly Media.
Sweigart, A. (2019). Automate the Boring Stuff with Python. No Starch Press.

lessons.title: Operators and Expressions
objectives: Perform mathematical calculations using arithmetic operators and understand the difference between floor and true division
Apply comparison operators to evaluate truth statements and control data flow
Utilize logical operators (and, or, not) to evaluate multi-condition boolean expressions
Apply the Order of Operations (PEMDAS) to resolve complex code expressions correctly
Manipulate text data using string concatenation and repetition operators
Implement basic user interaction using the input() and print() functions for dynamic expressions
content_outline: Prerequisite Review: Basic Algebra and Python Variable Assignment
Introduction to I/O: Capturing user input via input() and displaying results with print()
Arithmetic Operators: Basic math (+, -, *, /) vs. Floor Division (//), Modulo (%), and Exponentiation (**)
Comparison Operators: Evaluating equality (==, !=) and magnitude (>, <, >=, <=)
Logical Operators: Building complex truth statements with 'and', 'or', and 'not'
The Order of Operations: Applying PEMDAS/BODMAS in a programming context
Basic String Manipulation: Concatenation (+) and Repetition (*)
Augmented Assignment: Simplifying updates to variables (e.g., +=, -=)
activities: Interactive Input Drill: Create a program that asks for a user's name and birth year, then calculates and prints their approximate age
The 'Remainder' Challenge: Use the modulo operator to determine if dynamic user input is an even or odd number
Logical Gate Simulator: Predicting outcome values for nested logical expressions on paper before verifying in the IDE
Precedence Puzzle: Writing a single line of code that uses five different operators to reach a specific target number
Greeter Tool: Constructing a multi-line formatted string using string multiplication and concatenation
resources: Python 3.x IDLE, VS Code, or Jupyter Notebook environment
Python Tutor (pythontutor.com) for visualizing operator precedence and variable state
Digital Handout: 'Python Operator Cheat Sheet & PEMDAS Guide'
Exercise Set: 'Logical Operators and Truth Tables'
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). Expressions: Operator precedence. Python 3 Documentation.
Matthes, E. (2019). Python Crash Course: A Hands-On, Project-Based Introduction to Programming. No Starch Press.
Lutz, M. (2013). Learning Python: Powerful Object-Oriented Programming. O'Reilly Media.

lessons.title: Control Flow: Conditional Logic and User Input
objectives: Utilize the input() function to capture and cast user data for use in logic
Implement branching logic in programs using if, elif, and else statements
Evaluate complex boolean expressions using comparison and logical operators
Identify and apply the concept of truthiness and falsiness in Python objects
Construct nested conditional structures while maintaining readable code
content_outline: Prerequisite Review: Basic computer literacy and Python environment setup
Basic I/O: Capturing user input with input() and printing results with print()
Data Type Casting: Converting string input to integers/floats for logical comparison
Comparison Operators (==, !=, <, >, <=, >=) and Boolean types
The 'if' statement: Syntax, colon usage, and the significance of indentation (PEP 8)
Alternative paths: Using 'else' and 'elif' for mutually exclusive conditions
Logical Operators: Combining conditions with 'and', 'or', and 'not'
Pythonic Truthiness: Understanding Falsy values (0, '', None, []) vs Truthy values
Nested Conditionals and the 'Guard Clause' pattern to avoid deep nesting
activities: Code-along: Creating an interactive 'Admission Fee' calculator that asks for user age
Predictive Quiz: Determining the outcome of Truthy/Falsy evaluations in complex expressions
Debugging: Restructuring a 'deeply nested' block into a clean, flat conditional structure
Mini-Project: Text-based Decision Engine (Interpreting user text commands to navigate a scenario)
resources: Python 3.x Interpreter (following the installation guide from Lesson 1)
Visual execution tool: PythonTutor.com for tracing indentation-based logic
Official Python Documentation: 'More Control Flow Tools' and 'Built-in Functions (input)'
Logic Table Cheat Sheet: AND/OR/NOT operations summarized
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). 'More Control Flow Tools.' Python 3.12 Documentation.
Sweigart, A. (2019). 'Automate the Boring Stuff with Python.' No Starch Press.
Matthes, E. (2019). 'Python Crash Course.' No Starch Press.
Ambrose, S. A., et al. (2010). 'How Learning Works: Seven Research-Based Principles for Smart Teaching' (Evidence-based pedagogy reference for scaffolding logical concepts).

lessons.title: Iteration: Mastering Loops and Sequential Logic
objectives: Identify scenarios where automation through loops is more efficient than manual coding
Implement 'for' loops to iterate over text strings and list structures
Define and control 'while' loops using conditional logic to prevent infinite execution
Apply 'break' and 'continue' statements to modify loop flow dynamically based on runtime input
Utilize the 'range()' function to generate specific sequences of numbers for arithmetic iteration
content_outline: The Concept of Iteration: Automating repetitive tasks in computer memory
Prerequisite Review: Quick recap of Booleans and strings as sequential data
The 'for' loop: Syntax, indentation rules, and iterating through text/strings
Numeric ranges: Master the range(start, stop, step) function and its 'exclusive stop' behavior
The 'while' loop: Logic-driven repetition and the importance of updating control variables
Loop Control Flow: Using 'break' to exit and 'continue' to skip (The 'Early Exit' pattern)
Nested Loops: Introduction to hierarchical iteration (e.g., rows and columns)
Common Pitfalls: Preventing infinite loops and solving off-by-one errors
activities: Instructional Trace: Using 'Python Tutor' to visualize how variables change in memory during each loop cycle
Code Along: Printing the squares of numbers 1-10 using range() and formatted print statements
Debugging Challenge: Diagnosing and fixing a 'while' loop that lacks a decrement/increment, causing an infinite loop
Text Processor: Iterate through a user-provided string to count vowels, skipping consonants using 'continue'
Mini-Project: 'Secure Login' – Create a program that requests user input and grants 3 attempts before locking the system
Predictive Quiz: Analyzing code snippets with break/continue to determine the final value of trackers
resources: Python 3.x Interpreter (established in Lesson 1: Getting Started)
Python Tutor Visualizer (Online tool for tracing execution logic)
Official Python Documentation: Control Flow Tools (Section 4.2-4.4)
Guided Worksheet: 'The Logic of Range and Off-by-One Errors'
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). More Control Flow Tools. Python 3.12 Documentation.
Matthes, E. (2019). Python Crash Course: A Hands-On, Project-Based Introduction to Programming. No Starch Press.
Sweigart, A. (2019). Automate the Boring Stuff with Python. No Starch Press.
Ambrosio, M. (2021). Evidence-Based Pedagogy: The Role of Retrieval Practice in Programming Education.

lessons.title: Data Structures: Lists and Tuples
objectives: Identify the syntax and use cases for lists versus tuples
Explain the technical and practical differences between mutability and immutability relative to computer memory
Perform data manipulation using indexing, slicing, and built-in sequence methods
Apply basic text-processing techniques by converting strings to lists and vice versa
Implement tuple unpacking and list iteration to process structured datasets
content_outline: Introduction to Sequences: Defining square-bracket lists [] and parenthetical tuples ()
Memory and Mutability: How Python stores lists (dynamic) vs. tuples (fixed) in memory
Accessing Data: Deep dive into zero-based indexing and slicing [start:stop:step] mechanics
List Dynamics: Growing and shrinking collections with .append(), .insert(), .extend(), .pop(), and .remove()
Interfacing with Text: String manipulation using .split() and .join() to transition between text and lists
Tuple Mechanics: Performance benefits, data integrity, and the 'immutability' constraint
Advanced Assignment: Tuple unpacking and using the * (starred) expression for flexible data extraction
Traversal: Iterating through collections using 'for' loops (Logical progression from Lesson 5 Control Flow)
activities: Memory Visualization Lab: Use a Python visualizer to watch how 'mutating' a list changes a reference while 'changing' a tuple creates a new object
Text Processing Challenge: Take a multi-line string of user input, split it into a list of words, sort them, and join them back into a formatted paragraph
The 'Stack' Simulation: Implement a simple Undo/Redo mechanism using list .append() and .pop() methods
Structural Debugging: Practice identifying and fixing the 'TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment'
Inventory Report: Write a script that iterates through a list of tuples (representing item names and quantities) and prints a formatted status report
resources: Python Documentation: Section 3.1.3 (Lists) and 5.3 (Tuples and Sequences)
Jupyter Notebook: 'Lesson_6_Sequences_and_Text_Manipulation.ipynb'
Python Tutor (Online Visualizer): Tool for viewing memory allocation of mutable vs. immutable objects
Concept Map: When to use Lists vs. Tuples vs. Strings
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). Data Structures. Python 3.12 Documentation.
Matthes, E. (2019). Python Crash Course: A Hands-On, Project-Based Introduction to Programming. No Starch Press.
Ramalho, L. (2022). Fluent Python: Clear, Concise, and Effective Programming. O'Reilly Media.

lessons.title: Data Structures: Dictionaries and Sets
objectives: Map keys to values for efficient retrieval and understand the role of computer memory in storage
Manage unique item sets and utilize hash-based membership testing for performance
Differentiate between mutable and immutable types to identify requirements for hashability
Apply common dictionary and set methods to solve complex data organization problems
Integrate user input/output and string formatting within data structure manipulation
content_outline: Contextualizing Memory: How dictionaries and sets use hashing to achieve near-instant lookups compared to sequential lists.
Dictionary Fundamentals: Syntax, key-value pairs, and the importance of using descriptive string keys (Review of String literal usage).
Safe Data Retrieval: Accessing values, handling KeyErrors, and the utility of the .get() method for default values.
Dynamic Dictionary Management: Adding, updating, and removing entries using user input() data.
The Concept of Hashability: Deep dive into why keys must be immutable (Strings, Numbers, Tuples) and why mutable lists cannot be keys.
Set Fundamentals: Unordered collections, uniqueness constraints, and removing duplicates from noisy text data.
Mathematical Set Logic: Performing union (|), intersection (&), and difference (-) operations to analyze overlapping datasets.
Iteration and Formatting: Using .items() to generate formatted string reports from stored data structures.
activities: Interactive Terminal App: Build a 'Contact Manager' that takes user input to add names (keys) and phone numbers (values) to a dictionary.
Data Cleaning Lab: Take a list of strings containing duplicate names and use a Set to generate a unique list of participants.
Set Logic Challenge: Use intersection and difference operations to compare two lists of 'Registered Users' and 'Logged In Users'.
Debugging Workshop: Predict and fix the 'TypeError: unhashable type' when attempting to use a list as a dictionary key.
resources: Python Documentation: Mapping Types — dict
Python Documentation: Set Types — set, frozenset
PythonTutor.com: Visualizing references, memory addresses, and hash tables
VS Code or Replit for local/cloud development environment execution
citations: Van Rossum, G., & Drake, F. L. (2023). Python 3.12 documentation. Python Software Foundation.
Lutz, M. (2013). Learning Python: Powerful Object-Oriented Programming. O'Reilly Media.
Ramalho, L. (2022). Fluent Python: Clear, Concise, and Effective Programming. O'Reilly Media.
Ambrose, S. A., et al. (2010). How Learning Works: Seven Research-Based Principles for Smart Teaching. Jossey-Bass. (Basis for Evidence-Based Scaffolding).

lessons.title: Functions and Modular Code
objectives: Identify the syntax for defining and calling functions in Python.
Differentiate between parameters and arguments for data passing.
Implement return statements to output data from functions compared to printing.
Explain the difference between local and global variable scope using the LEGB rule.
Apply modular programming principles to refactor redundant code into reusable blocks.
content_outline: Prerequisite Review: Recap of basic input/output (input() and print()) and variable assignment
Introduction to DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principles and why we use functions
Defining functions: The 'def' keyword, naming conventions (snake_case), and mandatory indentation
Data Passing: Understanding parameters (placeholders) versus arguments (actual values)
Flow of Execution: How 'return' sends data back to the caller versus how 'print' displays data to the console
Variable Scope and Memory: Understanding the LEGB rule (Local, Enclosing, Global, Built-in)
Documentation: Writing docstrings for clarity and maintainability
Toward the Synthesis Project: How modular functions build the foundation for the final capstone project
activities: Live Coding: Create a 'Greeter' function that takes a name and returns a formatted string.
The Return vs. Print Lab: Modify an existing function to 'return' a value for use in a secondary calculation, demonstrating memory persistence.
Function Refactoring: Take a script with repeated math operations (from Lesson 3) and rewrite it using cohesive, single-responsibility functions.
Scope Challenge: Debug a script where local variables are incorrectly accessed globally, illustrating 'NameError' exceptions.
Building a Modular Calculator: Create a program where arithmetic operations are isolated functions, preparing for the Lesson 10 Synthesis Project.
resources: Python 3.x Documentation: Defining Functions
Python Tutor Visualizer: Stepping through code to see local vs. global scope in memory
VS Code or Replit Environment (setup covered in Lesson 1)
Guided Worksheet: Identifying DRY violations in legacy code
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). The Python Tutorial: Defining Functions. Python.org.
Lutz, M. (2013). Learning Python: Powerful Object-Oriented Programming. O'Reilly Media.
Sweigart, A. (2019). Automate the Boring Stuff with Python. No Starch Press.
Ambrose, S. A., et al. (2010). How Learning Works: Seven Research-Based Principles for Smart Teaching (Evidence-based Pedagogy Reference).

lessons.title: Error Handling and Debugging
objectives: Distinguish between syntax, logic, and runtime errors to apply the correct fix strategy
Interpret and navigate Python traceback messages to identify root causes of failures
Implement the try-except-else-finally architecture to manage runtime exceptions
Prevent program crashes by validating user input using proactive error handling
Apply basic debugging techniques using print statements and tracing logic
content_outline: The Three Tiers of Errors: Syntax (structure), Logic (incorrect results), and Runtime (exceptions)
Anatomy of a Traceback: Reading Python error logs from the bottom up to identify line numbers and exception types
Defensive Programming: Using input() validation to prevent errors before they occur
The Exception Handling Pattern: Syntax and execution flow of 'try' and 'except'
Precision Handling: Catching specific exceptions (ValueError, TypeError, ZeroDivisionError) to avoid silencing unrelated bugs
Advanced Flow Control: Using 'else' for code that runs only on success, and 'finally' for mandatory cleanup (e.g., closing files)
Debugging Strategies: Rubber ducking, manual tracing, and using print() effectively to inspect variable states
activities: The Crash Test: Students write a script that intentionally crashes (e.g., dividing by zero or converting 'abc' to an int) and then wrap it in a try/except block.
Traceback Scavenger Hunt: Students analyze three real-world error logs to pinpoint the exact line and cause of failure.
The Robust Interface: Refactor an input-based script from a previous lesson to handle non-numeric text input without crashing, using a 'while True' loop and try/except.
Logic Error Detective: Students are given a 'broken' script that runs without crashing but produces the wrong output; they must use print() statements to find the mathematical flaw.
resources: Integrated Development Environment (IDE) with a built-in terminal (VS Code, PyCharm, or Thonny)
Python Tutorial: Errors and Exceptions (Official Documentation)
Visual Python Tutor (online tool for stepping through code execution)
Worksheet: 'Common Python Exceptions and What They Mean'
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). Errors and Exceptions. Python 3.12 Documentation.
Matthes, E. (2023). Python Crash Course, 3rd Edition: A Hands-On, Project-Based Introduction to Programming. No Starch Press.
Fowler, M. (2018). Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code. Addison-Wesley Professional.

lessons.title: Persistent Data: File I/O and the Synthesis Project
objectives: Implement safe file handling using the 'with' statement and context managers to prevent memory leaks
Perform read and write operations on external text files using various access modes
Navigate file systems and resolve paths using the pathlib module for cross-platform stability
Synthesize all previously learned concepts (loops, logic, strings, and I/O) into a cohesive CLI application
content_outline: Prerequisite Review: Basic Input/Output (input() and print()) and String manipulation techniques
Introduction to Context Managers: How 'with' manages computer memory and ensures OS file closure
File Access Modes: Deep dive into 'r' (read), 'w' (write), 'a' (append), and '+ ' (updating)
Reading vs. Writing: Practical usage of .read(), .readlines(), .write(), and .writelines()
Modern Path Management: Using pathlib.Path to avoid errors across Windows and Unix-like systems
Exception Handling: Using try/except blocks for FileNotFoundError and PermissionError
Defining the Synthesis Project: Explanation of a 'Synthesis Project' as a cumulative assessment combining variables, logic, strings, and persistence
activities: Warm-up: Create a persistent 'Activity Log' that appends timestamps to a text file using 'a' mode
Data Parsing Practice: Open a text file and use string methods (.split, .strip) to clean and extract specific values
Guided Coding: Implement a robust file-check utility that validates file existence before attempting a read
Synthesis Project (The Data Summarizer): Develop a CLI tool that reads a source file (e.g., sales.txt), performs mathematical calculations on the data, and writes a formatted 'Summary_Report.txt'
resources: Official Python Documentation: Reading and Writing Files
Tutorial: String Methods and Text Processing in Python
Project Starter Kit: raw_sales_data.txt and template_script.py
Python 3.x Standard Library: pathlib documentation
citations: Python Software Foundation. (2023). Input and Output. Python 3.12 Documentation.
Sweigart, A. (2019). Automate the Boring Stuff with Python: Practical Programming for Total Beginners. No Starch Press (Chapter 9: Reading and Writing Files).
Ambrose, S. A., et al. (2010). How Learning Works: Seven Research-Based Principles for Smart Teaching. Jossey-Bass (Defining Synthesis in Pedagogical Frameworks).

lessons.title: Data Structures: Lists and Tuples

Memory and Mutability: How Python stores lists (dynamic) vs. tuples (fixed) in memory
Accessing Data: Deep dive into zero-based indexing and slicing [start:stop:step] mechanics
List Dynamics: Growing and shrinking collections with .append(), .insert(), .extend(), .pop(), and .remove()
Interfacing with Text: String manipulation using .split() and .join() to transition between text and lists

lessons.title: Data Structures: Dictionaries and Sets

Set Fundamentals: Unordered collections, uniqueness constraints, and removing duplicates from noisy text data.

quality_score.feedback: This is a well-structured, comprehensive syllabus for a Python fundamentals course. The progression from basic syntax to more complex concepts is logical and pedagogically sound. The lesson titles are clear, objectives are specific and measurable, and topics are appropriately scoped for each lesson. The course builds toward a practical synthesis project, which provides good application of learned concepts.
issues: Lesson 1 objectives could be more challenging - 'Execute basic print statements' is very minimal; consider adding something about understanding program execution flow.
Lesson 9 appears before file I/O (Lesson 10), but error handling is often more meaningful when applied to file operations; consider reorganizing or integrating error handling with file I/O.
No explicit mention of string formatting or f-strings, which are fundamental Python features.
The syllabus doesn't mention code style (PEP 8) or documentation/comments, which are important for beginners.
While the course objective mentions 'evidence-based pedagogy,' the syllabus structure doesn't explicitly show how this pedagogy is implemented in lesson design or assessments.

gaps_found: Lesson 3 (Operators and Expressions) appears before Lesson 4 (Control Flow: Conditional Logic and User Input), but operators are typically introduced alongside or immediately before conditional logic to enable practical application. The separation might create a gap where learners understand operators but can't yet use them meaningfully in programs.

Lesson 9 (Error Handling and Debugging) comes after Lesson 8 (Functions and Modular Code), but basic debugging concepts (like print statements) should be introduced much earlier when learners start writing code that might fail.

The transition from Lesson 5 (Iteration) to Lesson 6 (Data Structures) is logical, but there's no explicit mention of how loops will be applied to data structures - this connection should be emphasized.
missing_prerequisites: No explicit lesson on basic programming concepts before diving into Python syntax (e.g., what is a program, algorithms, computational thinking).
No early introduction to basic debugging techniques or reading error messages - essential for beginners when they inevitably make syntax errors.
No mention of code comments or documentation practices, which should be introduced early to encourage good habits.
unclear_concepts: The relationship between 'Logic' in the course title and the actual content isn't clear from the lesson titles alone.
What 'evidence-based pedagogy' means in practice isn't explained for the beginner.
The 'Synthesis Project' in Lesson 10 sounds advanced but has no context - what skills will it synthesize?
The distinction between 'Data Foundations' (Lesson 2) and 'Operators and Expressions' (Lesson 3) might be confusing - are they separate concepts or deeply intertwined?
recommendations: Add a preliminary lesson on computational thinking and what programming actually is before diving into Python.
Introduce basic debugging techniques earlier (perhaps in Lesson 2 or 3) when learners first encounter errors.
Consider combining Lessons 3 and 4 to show operators in the context of conditional logic.
Add a lesson between 5 and 6 that bridges loops and data structures explicitly.
Include code documentation/comments as an early lesson or integrate throughout.
Clarify what 'synthesis' means in the final project - list specific skills from previous lessons that will be combined.
